This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

First of all, we have to define what we mean by 'blacks have lower IQs'.

In the past it was the common belief that all black people had lower IQs than all white people. This is obviously false (and it's what the left mean when they talk about racism, because it's much easier for them to win their argument if they keep using this strawman).

I think we can all agree that if - if - blacks have lower IQs, we mean that blacks have lower IQs on average. For example, if you put a hundred white people in a room then 15 of them will have IQs above 115 (one standard deviation above the norm), but in a room with a hundred black people only two or three of them will have an IQ above 115.

So there are black people with high IQs, just far fewer of them relative to the size of the black population. And likewise, more blacks with subnormal IQs. So what do we do about this?

Answer: treat them as individuals

When you're dealing with a black individual, treat them like you would anyone else: judge them on the characteristics they present to you. If a black person applies for a job under you, you don't need to judge them on their skin tone, you have their CV. If someone introduces a black person to your social group, judge them on how they act. And if it turns out they're an idiot, then treat them like a white person who's an idiot.

And if the aggregate of judging each on their individual merits is that blacks as a group have on average worse outcomes than whites, then we just accept that.

Affirmative action is never going to produce the desired results, and by treating them as a single block with the same background and the same needs, we've only been handicapping the small number of black people who're capable of reaching high-level positions on their own merits. We haven't created a self-sustaining black middle class, and we've condemned many of those who could have succeeded to the dead-end of tokenism.

>>14382694
>What did the scythians look like?
The word 'Scythian' has multiple meanings: It refers to a tribe of people on the Pontic steppe, who are recorded by the Greeks (Skoloti), but it also refers to other ethnically non-Scythian groups on the steppe whose way of life resembled the Scythian one and who are thus only "Scythian" by association.

The ethnic Scythians of Greek history most likely looked like a mixture of Ukrainians, Uralics and Tajiks.
The "Scythians-by-association" were far more diverse in appearance, since they included many different tribes and ethnicities, and looked anything inbetween Udmurts and Kazakhs.
What I said above is reflected in all legit ancient PCAs, like in >>14382845.

>are the rumours of the scots and irish being descendants of the scythians true?
Not at all. Scots and Irish are genetically extremely distant to anything that could possibly be labeled Scythian. The myth arose through a national LARP, where Scottish monks thought that their was a connection between the "Scyt" (fr. Σκυθοι, Scythian) and the Scots (Scottish people), purely by similar sounding names. It’s idiotic really.

Hello, i would like to talk about a topic never mentionned, not known at all, even from 99% of Moroccans themselves due to the later events overshadowing it

As a Moroccan and /his/tory lover i started to study more and more industrialisation around the world, how some places had all the necessary to be the first ones to start industrialisation, how it spreaded from England to all over the world, where did it fail etc... and Most peoples take Industrialisation as an European history when its more of a Western European history, the rest of europe only got industrialized by being conquered by those major western powers ( except for Russia which is eastern but at that time thanks to monarchy was deeply linked to other western empires )

And then, there's the Ottoman empire, which got industrialised but not to an extant like western europe, they undoubtedly had their weapon factories, daily life industrial tools etc... but it was really mainly concentrated around Turkish heartland and Balkan Ottoman Empire, the rest of Arab states weren't being developped at all and were kept as village and farm populated place with very few cities unindustrialized mainly due to the fact that all MENA countries didn't have a big population that would prop up industrialization, but also due to Ottomans not wanting to make Arabs self sufficient, but rather force them to keep buying products made in Turkish factories.

He ordered total reorganization of the army, copying western style of armies and making the army a job, and not just peoples becoming soldiers when in war, he copied western style of training and understood the importance of separating soldiers from the cities by building training camps, where order and dicipline was teached, in picrel you can see the results, Ottomans becoming too weak relied on Egypt multiple times to conquer revolting place up until Egypt itself advanced toward Ottoman core territory before UK forcing egypt to stop in a fear that the fall of Ottomans would mean more Russian control in the balkans.

The reason was linked to battles, against other powers but also in Morocco.
What happened from 1850 to 1900 wasn't just Morocco learning slowly to industrialize, it was also mainly how Moroccan state became too sick to function properly, and became a constantly fighting country to ensure itself few more decades of existence, during 19th century Morocco saw its entire surrounding being conquered by Western europeans, becoming alone isolated between French and Spanish territories, Morocco usually just had to fortify its northern part and north western coast against Spanish and Portugese attempts at conquering lands, it also managed to maintain its presence on the East when it had to fight the Ottomans and Algerian Regency during late 18th century, but it never had or could maintain its Eastern Saharan borders, notably because those were just trade routes, no other state could attack Morocco, and Moroccan army only crossed these borders to conquer subsaharan kingdoms for slaves and gold, so only expeditionnary forces, but never stationnary presence. which truely signed an end to Moroccan habit of fending off stronger European armies trying to invade it because this time its not coming from the north, this time in 1830 France conquered Algeria then subsaharan Africa and Sahara which made it possible for Morocco to be attacked from the south and east. picrel you can see the conquest of Algeria and Sahara, and the loss of Moroccan saharan territories that weren't defended at all

Cont

From there Morocco's downfall started due to economic reasons, peoples tend to think that colonization of MENA was uniquely an army advancing on MENA countries, but it was also treaties, debts, ambassadors or leaders from both countries negociating etc...
in 1844 Moroccan king, seeing the total conquest of Neighboring Algeria decided to help the local counter colonization leader the Emir Abd el-Kader
This help was in form of weapon donations, hosting Algerian rebels behind Moroccan borders, sending Moroccan militias fighting against France, all of that pushed France to take actions and ask Moroccan king Abd alrahman to remove all help or face war, Moroccan king stayed vague and denied providing help to Algerians, France declared war, a war that was quick but had heavy consequences, the Battle of Isly saw Oujda, a big Moroccan city next to the Algerian ( now French ) border being conquered quickly thanks to French strategic formation rendering Moroccan fast horse mounted attack ineffective despite 45000 Moroccans with canon pieces fighting 10 000 french troops, the French navy also sent 20 warships along Western Moroccan coasts where main cities are, shelling first the northern city of Tangier heavily protected itself by moroccan canons aimed toward the sea, despite heavy Moroccan fighting the battle ended in few hours due to French guns being more precise, destroying a lot of Moroccan canons, but also shelling the city, same thing happened in Essaouira a bit later notably where France destroyed most Moroccan coastal defenses but saw 40 Moroccan canons holding positions and keeping intense fire on french ships, followed by French troops disembarking on a small island
Moroccan king capitulated to avoid more political loss and negociate statut quo

The city of Oujda was given back and war ended but Morocco had to pay heavy war tribute to France, in 1851 another shortlived battle occured between France and Morocco without results, in 1859 a war against Spain was started after multiple raids from local moroccans on spanish territory of Ceuta which the Moroccan gov or army did nothing to prevent it or repair it, the war was declared and saw 50 000 spanish troops invading the north fighting against 50 000 Moroccan troops, the fight was symetrical because the losses were similar, but peace was signed in 1860 again at the price of huge war reparations which is why when Morocco tried to industrialize in the years 1880 it didn't go anywhere due to Morocco having multiple debts to pay, debts Morocco couldn't ignore due to the risk of France and Spain colonizing Morocco like the rest of Africa was, from there the collapse of Moroccan state and power started, the country got poorer, the taxes increased to pay these reparations, adding few consecutive years of bad weather that caused few famines and civil unrest, the Political structure of the Moroccan empire, based on constant war and conquest was now over, the power of the king outside of the core of Morocco ( coastal morocco around Rabat, Casablanca etc... ) relied on local rulers submitting to the king and ensuring taxation in exchange of getting paid and being ensured power on their local town, the Moroccan army heavily relied on Black slaves which were separate from the society and treated better, they formed the royal guard army and at the time were 30 000, ( they were 150 000 one century before ) they were prefered to Moroccan soldiers due to their total submission and loyalty to the king when Moroccans soldiers were feared because would have created infighting for power. a small european like Moroccan army was also formed but it only regrouped the most valuable assets of Moroccan army which was artillery and the few remaining warships

I'd say we need to acknowledge cultural Christianity but be extremely exclusive when speaking about religious Christianity.

>The rite of passage undergone by Greek youths in the tribal prehistory of Greece evolved into the commonly known form of Greek pederasty after the rise of the city-state, or polis. Greek boys no longer left the confines of the community, but rather paired up with older men within the confines of the city. These men, like their earlier counterparts, played an educational and instructive role in the lives of their young companions; likewise, just as in earlier times, they shared a sexual relationship with their boys. Penetrative sex, however, was seen as demeaning for the passive partner, and outside the socially accepted norm.[11] In ancient Greece, sex was generally understood in terms of penetration, pleasure, and dominance, rather than a matter of the sexes of the participants. According to Dover, pederasty was not considered to be a homosexual act, given that the ‘man’ would be taking on a dominant role, and his disciple would be taking on a passive one. When intercourse occurred between two people of the same gender, it still was not entirely regarded as a homosexual union, given that one partner would have to take on a passive role, and would therefore no longer be considered a ‘man’ in terms of the sexual union.[12] Hubbard and James Davidson argue however that there is insufficient evidence that a man was considered effeminate for being passive in sex alone. For example, the lowborn protagonist of Aristophanes' play The Knights openly admits to having been a passive partner.[13]

posts.com:
What does /his/ think of the hypothesis that 2003 invasion of Iraq was about oil? It was a popular hypothesis in the early to mid 00s, but fell out of favor pretty rapidly during the 2010s. Now most people dismiss it entirely, saying that the United States gets most of its oil domestically and from Canada anyway and doesn't give a shit about Iraqi oil.

But I think that's projecting present experience onto the past. People were shit scared of peak oil during the 00s, the peak oil movement had over 100,000 "peakists" at its peak (heh). The 1970s oil shocks weren't too long ago and the United States still had an apprensive paranoia at spiking oil prices, and they were going up since the glut in the 80s, and showed no signs of slowing down.

I don't believe that the United States literally invaded to seize Iraqi oil to export it to the United States. But I do believe they came down hard to prevent OPEC from having another oil producing member that could throw its weight around in the middle east, and to prevent Ba'thist Iraq from being a wildcard in the Middle Eastern balance of power.

De-Baathification in Iraq came with the privatizing of the oil fields. Full privatization was underway and it was only a changing of circumstances, with dropping oil demand due to the financial recession and the fracking boom in the States, that made the US government relent on the most extreme elements of privatization.

So the media machine was fired up, and narratives of WMD threats (because Hussein wouldn't allow inspectors to enter) along with general anti-terrorism sentiment at the time was used as a tool to get people on board with the initial surge. Later, this was transformed into an "experiment" of sorts in "democracy." Unfortunately, ISIS appeared in 2014, undoing what had been done in much of the country and causing another resurgence in global terrorism anyway.

I do think the Bush's foreign policy was tailored with oil scarcity in mind, and the administration expected to be entering a new paradigm in regards to the commodity. The alliance with the Sauds had only been going on for 18 years at the time and wasn't seen as reliable. I do believe that there was a strong possibility that if oil scarcity became a serious problem and Iraq got back on its feet, there was a possibility of a Saudi/Iraq rapprochement. The worst autistic tantrums the Arabs had over Israel were over at that point, and there wasn't much chance of the States getting back in with Iran. The US would've ended up locked out of the middle east and be unable to dictate the flow of oil leaving the region.

Russia was also exerting its own independence under Putin and gone were the days of the 90s when the States could literally dictate terms. The OPEC crisis was only mitigated in Europe in the 70s by the Brezhnev administrations eagerness to get its hand on foreign cash. A rising Russia without the retarded communist economic system might be in a position to not bail Europe out next time, and going by how much Europe suffered without Russian oil this time, this theory has been pretty well vindicated. A repeat of the 70s without Russian gas would've horrifically tanked the European economy, to the point where it'd take over a decade to recover.

All this seems somewhat silly now only because we've had a fracking boom and a rise in unconventional oil. The oil hypothesis for the Iraq war makes the most sense, and can explain every part of the war sufficiently. The idealistic war on terror explanation can't.

>>14381848
Your description of the Catholic position is wrong.

Catholics do not believe the elements of the Eucharist remain bread and wine after consecration. Upon consecration they cease being bread and wine and instead truly become Jesus.

Notice how the word "truly" is used instead of "literally". Theologians avoid saying the sacramental bread and wine literally become Jesus because that would imply a physical transformation of the elements into the body and blood of Christ, the ritual eating of which would make us cannibals. No, instead we say the elements transubstantiate, so that they become Christ not in the literal physical sense, but in the true spiritual sense, it is truly Christ, but spiritually. Only in very rare extraordinary circumstances have the elements literally become Christ's body and blood, this is called a Eucharistic miracle.

Because the elements are truly Christ, they are truly God, and are worshipped.

Also, one last aspect to note is that there is a symbolic dimension to the elements. While we profess Christ's true presence in the sacrament we don't believe the bread only is Christ's flesh, and the wine is only Christ's blood, rather the bread is symbolic of Christ's flesh and the wine symbolic of Christ's blood while in both elements Christ in his fullness truly becomes present so that we consume all of Christ.

>>14385161
Protestants have a variety of views. Lutherans believe the substance of the bread and wine becomes united to the substance of Christ's body and blood, but the bread and wine continue to remain as realities in themselves apart from Christ, therefore they say the bread and wine remain and don't actually become Christ, though Christ is still corporeally present under the forms of the species in Lutheranism, as in Catholicism and Orthodoxy (they use different theological terms).

Reformed seem to take Christ seriously when he said he'd be present with those who gathered in his name, they understand Jesus as spiritually present in the Eucharist, yes, but not corporeally, the bread and wine always remain as symbols, Christ is present in the bread and wine through the Holy Spirit and actually Christ becomes present more so in the believer when the believer partakes of the bread and wine.

As for Anglicans and Methodists, neither have a truly articulated understanding. The thirty nine artciels in Anglicanism have a view similar to the Reformed understanding. Anglicans and Methodists see Christ as truly present in the bread and wine, but how this happens, what this means, is not known or really elaborated on much. It's a mystery. They would, however, totally deny transubstantiation, this is the only doctrine of the real presence they outright deny, and agree the bread and wine remain bread and wine.

Baptists tend to take a Reformed understanding, but more so in the line of Zwingli rather than Calvin, though so called Reformed Baptists may take the Calvinist understanding; they basically deny any true real presence and say Christ is present only in the memorial, not in any actual true sense. For them, the ritual is symbolic only. Also, because they abstain from Alcohol, they use grape juice instead of wine in the Lord's Supper as they cal it. Methodists do that too actually.

No. It was more in the nature of an accelerant. The KMT (Or GMD, depending on how you want to anglicize it) operated more like a medieval system of vassalage than a modern nation-state. They had their strongholds in and around Guangdong and near Nanjing, but lacked the administrative capacity to really rule much more than that. So they allowed a bunch of semi-independent warlords to run pretty much the rest of China as long as those warlords send periodic tributes of money and manpower.

But their abilities to actually rein in those warlords were very limited. Go look up the Central Plains War, well before the Japanese invaded. Chiang could march north and win all the battles, send the senior members of the clique against him into exile, and then they stay away for a year or two, come back, and it's back to business as usual.

Without the ability to actually run China, there are always going to be hostile groups that slip into the cracks in the power structure, which meant that the KMT could at best hold the communists to a stalemate, never really get rid of them. That sort of war only ends one way.

While the Japanese invasion very much weakened the KMT, they were already in trouble before it happened; and the invasion was itself a product of Nationalist weakness, not the cause of it.

Should we assume that whoever first told the story meant it mostly allegorically?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14384042
>How did pagan religions evolve?

Pagan Religions, like all Religions, started out as folk religions meant to explain and worship the gods of gaps: "I don't know how this natural phenomena (disease, tides, phases of the moon, seasons) happens, so it must be the work of the gods/spirits/elementals." People worshipped rocks, trees, animals, the wind, the sun, they prayed directly to the things that decided whether they would live or die.

Eventually though when things started to get a little more developed and you had some guarantee you weren't going to be eaten by a tiger or a hominid; people's pagan beliefs became more structured. Pagan religions started compiling regional folk beliefs into single, organized, institutionalized religious organizations surrounded around maybe a city or even a king. In the bronze age and classical periods is was very popular to conceive of either your ruler as a demigod or the city-state you lived in to be patroned by a god. At this point the embellishment of ancestors and their worship also began. People had always prayed for the restful sleeps of their dead, but now people were beginning to get sanctified and deified as better oral and written record keeping allowed the stories of people to be passed down, and embellished, for generations. An example of this kind of belief system taken to this "logical extreme" is probably Judaism. Judaism started out with a whole entire pantheon of gods, but they eventually settled on one, saw him as their progenitor god, themselves as chosen people, etc.. etc.. Judaism is basically just a grandfathered Pagan Religion.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14384286

With that in mind there was a 3rd stage of development that happened in India, China, and a little bit in Greece; where literacy and education began to debunked folk-answers to natural phenomena and create unsatisfied intellectuals. Philosophers, naturalists, alchemists, saw "old pagan superstitions" as insufficient, became critical of them, and began looking for more meaningful answers to life's "bigger" questions: "Why am I here?" "What is my purpose?" "Who made God?" "What is the source of suffering?" "Is there anything I truly can explore?" high concept questions.

These thoughts and philosophical developments lead to the "high theory" characteristics, and with accompanying bigger "gaps" to disprove and thus worship. Buddhism specifically managed to persist as a pagan religion, and spread so wildly despite the fact, because it could not only adopt and retain pagan folk beliefs (look up folk Buddhism sometime), but also provide more "higher meaning" to fart-sniffing scholars and secular-types.

I'll also add a footnote that as things got more developed, secular thinking proliferated, etc.. Some pagan religions DIDN'T go the route of "high theory contemplative" thought and just continued to operate as a function of the state.
Rome, Japan, China, all had their own state/court religions that more or less only existed to legitimize the right to rule and the various claims of the throne. Rome had this... kind of state sanctifying program that I'm only vaguely aware of where if you were a "really good bureaucrat/ruler" you just got to be a god with a statue in their temples. China had at different times the belief that Chinese Emperors were either descendant of dragons or otherwise chosen by an Emerald Heavenly divine court, and if they fucked up the land would just turn against them "Mandate of Heaven" style. Meanwhile Japan had State Shinto that dictated the Emperor was the closest living relative to Japan's progenitor god and that's why he's the Emperor.

I'm paraphrasing all of this of course, but that's the "general" situation.

Despite a number of publications saying the opposite, a DNA test is not considered evidence that can be used to justify immigration to Israel. This is because Israeli authorities often suspect that a person or their family may have converted to another religion, which would disqualify them from immigration to Israel. There are many cases we have seen where a family is secular, often from the former Soviet Union, and has not converted to another religion; however, they cannot provide documents proving their Jewish ancestry. In these cases, unfortunately, it is almost impossible to immigrate to Israel. In some very rare cases, a DNA test can be used to prove their relation to a Jewish parent or sibling, but documentation of the parent’s or sibling’s Jewishness would need to be clear.

A DNA test can be used to obtain Israeli citizenship, but this is reserved to prove that a person is the child of an Israeli citizen. According to Israeli law, if a child is born to an Israeli mother or father abroad, they can be granted Israeli citizenship. The DNA test is used to authorize this, proving this familial link. We discuss more about obtaining a paternity test in Israel in another article.

>>14383714
Broadly speaking there are 5 major branches of Christianity.

Catholics
Orthodox
Historical/tradition Protestant
Reformed Protestant
Evangelical

Christianity is a bit like water in that it takes the shape of the host culture. Many of the "traditions" of a specific church are just manifestation of the people within it. There is a reason that Roman Catholics dress like Romans, and American Baptists like Americans.

It's really hard to get a clear picture on what early Christianity looked like because the style of worship and practice changed as Christianity's relationship with the Roman Empire changed. The core theology remained the same, and between all 5 major branches is still extremely similar (trinitarian, baptism & communion, heaven & hell, etc). However, the idea of "early Christianity" is a red herring as it implies that there was a single precise answer to every question laid down from day one with not growth, which isn't true or believed by anyone.

Speaking extremely broadly, Catholics and Orthodox both make the same kinds of claims. They claim that Jesus instituted a clear and visible physical church that would be protected by the holy spirit from error and that they (Catholics or Orthodox) are the ones who maintain and have inherited that tradition and are the singular church. Where Catholics and Orthodox differ is that Catholics maintain that Jesus created a unique and special office for Peter that was above all others, did not require the consent of anyone else, and was divinely protected from error. Orthodox maintain that Peter had a place of honour above the other apostles but what not sovereign over them. Tldr pope or no? There are lots and lots of other differences that stem from their 1000 year split, but this is the simplest view.

There are fundamental differences between Indian civilization what is seen in China and Europe
India was a land of immense genetic diversity. What we call 'Indian civilization'(categorizing civilizations by regional zones is a flawed cold war ideology but I digress) was in essence a cultural hegemony of the Aryans, Gangetics, and Dravidians over the other tribes. India had never been united, and Indian states tended to be decentralized and short lived. This is a pattern that can bee seen with the Muslim excursions into India and the British Raj itself, with the states that crop up rarely surviving for very long, due to the demographic reality of India festering like a tumor. It is simply a land too diverse for real imperialism.
A second major difference is that the priest takes precedent to the warrior and even the King. Indian chroniclers before the Arab conquest usually wrote down martial history as myths and parables rather than real history to foster Hindu virtues in students. As a people, they simply weren't that interested in war

posts.com: >The earliest depiction of Muhammad in the West is found in a 12th-century manuscript of the Corpus Cluniacense. The image is intentionally defamatory, portraying Muhammad with a bearded human face and a fish-like body. It is perhaps inspired by Horaces Ars poetica, wherein the poet imagines "a woman, lovely above, foully ended in an ugly fish below" and asks if you would "restrain your laughter, my friends, if admitted to this private view?", a passage alluded to by Peter the Venerable in his account of Islam in the Corpus. This depiction, however, did not set the paradigm for later depictions.
